title: Sonnet 76 - characterizes the development of poem

content.description: Read the following carefully before you choose your answers. William Shakespeare's Sonnet 76 was published in 1609. Why is my verse so barren of new pride? So far from variation or quick change? Why with the time do I not glance aside To new-found methods and to compounds strange? 5Why write I still all one, ever the same, And keep invention in a noted weed, That every word doth almost tell my name, Showing their birth, and where they did proceed? O know, sweet love, I always write of you, 10And you and love are still my argument; So all my best is dressing old words new, Spending again what is already spent: For as the sun is daily new and old, So is my love, still telling what is told.
content.question: Which of the following best characterizes the development of the poem as a whole?

choices.label: The speaker acknowledges a weakness in his writing, only to turn this weakness into a means of affirming his devotion to his beloved.
The speaker laments a flaw in his character, then seeks to gain his belovedâ€™s sympathy by emphasizing his wretchedness.
The speaker asserts his indifference to literary fashions, then argues that his independence of mind makes him a more faithful lover.
The speaker expresses doubts about his poetic talents, then reassures himself by recalling the steadfast devotion of his beloved.

content.answer: The speaker acknowledges a weakness in his writing, only to turn this weakness into a means of affirming his devotion to his beloved.

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Explain the function of structure in a text.
